chapter.title: Domain, Range and Piecewise Defined Functions

li.p: Determine the domain and range of a function.
Determine from a graph or an equation whether a function is continuous or discontinuous.
Define, distinguish, and apply piecewise-defined functions.

subsection.title: Domain and Range
subsection.p: Sometimes a formula can only accept certain kinds of values. For instance the square root function f(x) = \sqrt x can only accept values of x are NOT negative.
In math we say x \geqslant 0 meaning the values we choose for x must be greater than or equal to zero.
The Domain of a function is the set of all the inputs that a function can use. for f(x) = \sqrt x the domain is x \geqslant 0 because these are the only values the function can use.
Another example is f(x) = \frac{x}{{{x^2} - 1}}. In this case the denominator could be zero (a big no-no) if x is either 1 or -1. So the domain if this function si All numbers except x = 1 or x = -1.
An easier way to say the same thing is to state what values you CAN'T use, as in x \ne \pm 1

For now the only functions that should raise re flags are those that have square roots (because you can't take the square root of negative numbers) and those with deonominators (because we have to avoid any numbers that give us zero in the denominator).
Once we know what numbers a function can use, we can then consider what kinds of results we can get. This is called the Range of the function.
For example, the square root function f(x) = \sqrt {x - 8} has a domain such that x-8 must be positive. Therefor the domain is
Under these conditions the function will never yeild negative results. Only y = 0 or positive results will ever come out of this function. Therefore the Range of f(x) is f(x) \geqslant 0
Domain and Range are often more clear if we look at functions graphically. Below is a graph of f(x) = \sqrt {x - 8}
Notice the graph only appears from x = 8 and to the right. That's the domain of f(x).
Also notice that the graph only appears at or above the x- axis (y = 0 or y > 0). That is the range of f(x) (i.e. range is f(x) \geqslant 0)
